analyzed: param maraṇā tesam ete paṭikkosanti

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?

analyzed: tayida bhikkhave tathāgataḥ abhijānāti
translated: “Bhikkhus, the Tathagata has known, as it actually is, the origination of perception, its cessation, its gratification, its danger, and the escape from it.

translated: “Either percipient of unity or of diversity or neither,🔽“Either happy or miserable or neither,🔽“Either with or without perception,🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of unity after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of diversity after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of neither unity nor diversity after death describe it as:

translated: “Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of happiness after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of misery after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of neither-misery-nor-happiness after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of unity after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of diversity after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of neither-unity-nor-diversity after death describe it as:

translated: “Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of happiness after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of misery after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of neither-misery-nor-happiness after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as with perception after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as without perception after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as with or without perception after death describe it as:

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā diṭṭhasutamutaviññātabbasaṅkhāramattena🔽etassa āyatanassa upasampadaṁ paññapenti, byasanañhetaṁ, bhikkhave, akkhāyati etassa🔽āyatanassa upasampadāya.

translated: “Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as neither with perception nor without perception after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of unity after death describe it as:🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as percipient of diversity after death

original: Na hetaṁ, bhikkhave, āyatanaṁ saṅkhārasamāpattipattabbamakkhāyati;🔽saṅkhārāvasesasamāpattipattabbametaṁ, bhikkhave, āyatanamakkhāyati.
analyzed: na heta bhikkhave āyatanam saṅkhāra samāpatti pattabbam akkhāyati  saṅkhāra avasesa samāpatti pattabbam eta bhikkhave āyatanam akkhāyati
translated: “Monks, this realm is not declared to be one that can be reached by attaining the cessation that is a compounded state.🔽This realm is declared to be one that can be reached by attaining the cessation that is a remainderless cessation of conditioning.

original: ‘Tayidaṁ saṅkhataṁ oḷārikaṁ atthi kho pana saṅkhārānaṁ nirodho atthetan’ti—
analyzed: tayā idam saṅkhatam oḷārikam atthi kho pana saṅkhārānam nirodhaḥ attha itanti
translated: ‘This, then, is fabricated, gross: but there is an ending of fabrications.’

original: iti viditvā tassa nissaraṇadassāvī tathāgato tadupātivatto.
analyzed: iti viditvā tassa nissaraṇa dassāvī tathāgato tad upātivatto
translated: Having known, ‘There is a further escape,’ the Tathāgata has gone beyond.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ vibhavaṁ paññapenti,
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā sataḥ sattassa ucchedam vināsam vibhavam paññapenti
translated: “Therein, monks, as for those contemplatives & brahmans who declare the annihilation, extermination, or destruction of an existent being—

original: tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā saññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti arogaṁ paraṁ maraṇā🔽tesamete paṭikkosanti, yepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā asaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti arogaṁ🔽paraṁ maraṇā tesamete paṭikkosanti, yepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā nevasaññīnāsaññiṁ
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā saññim attānam paññapenti arogam param maraṇā  tesam ete paṭikkosanti ye pi te bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ asaññim attānam paññapenti aroga  param tesam ete paṭikkosanti ye pi te bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ nevasaññī nāsaññi
translated: “Therein, monks, as for those contemplatives & brahmans who describe a self that possesses perception as sensitive, not subject to complete reversal after death:🔽They refute those good contemplatives & brahmans who describe a self that is without perception as sensitive, not subject to complete reversal after death.

original: attānaṁ paññapenti arogaṁ paraṁ maraṇā tesamete paṭikkosanti.
analyzed: attānam paññapenti arogam param maraṇā tesam ete paṭikkosanti
translated: They refute those good contemplatives & brahmans who describe a self that is both with & without perception as sensitive, not subject to complete reversal after death.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: “And why is that?

original: Sabbepime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhaṁ saraṁ āsattiṁyeva abhivadanti:
analyzed: sabbe pi ime bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddham saram āsattiyā iva abhivadanti
translated: All these good recluses and brahmins proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of a being who is a certain existent.

original: ‘iti pecca bhavissāma, iti pecca bhavissāmā’ti.
analyzed: iti pecca bhavissāma iti pecca bhavissāma ati
translated: ‘Thus we will be after death, thus we will not be after death; thus we will be and will not be after death; thus we will neither be nor not be after death.’

original: Seyyathāpi nāma vāṇijassa vāṇijjāya gacchato evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: seyyathā api nāma vāṇijassa vāṇijjāya gacchataḥ evam hoti
translated: Just as a trader might think:

original: ‘ito me idaṁ bhavissati, iminā idaṁ lacchāmī’ti;
analyzed: itas me idam bhavissati iminā idam lacchāmi iti
translated: ‘From this I will get that; from that I will get something else,’

original: evamevime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā vāṇijūpamā maññe paṭibhanti:
analyzed: evam eva ime bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ vāṇijūpamāḥ maññe paṭibhanti
translated: so these good recluses and brahmins seem to be like traders when they say:

original: ‘iti pecca bhavissāma, iti pecca bhavissāmā’ti.
analyzed: iti pecca bhavissāma iti pecca bhavissāma ati
translated: ‘Thus we will be after death, thus we will not be after death; thus we will be and will not be after death; thus we will neither be nor not be after death.’

original: Tayidaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato abhijānāti.
analyzed: tayida bhikkhave tathāgataḥ abhijānāti
translated: The Tathagata, bhikkhus, understands this thus.

original: Ye kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ vibhavaṁ paññapenti te sakkāyabhayā sakkāyaparijegucchā sakkāyaññeva anuparidhāvanti anuparivattanti.
analyzed: ye kho te bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā sataḥ sattassa ucchedam vināsam vibhavam paññapenti te sakkāya bhayā sakkāya parijegucchā sakkāyaññā iva anuparidhāvanti anuparivattanti
translated: Those good recluses and brahmins who proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of a being who is a certain existent run and circle around that same identity,

original: Seyyathāpi nāma sā gaddulabaddho daḷhe thambhe vā khile vā upanibaddho, tameva thambhaṁ vā khilaṁ vā anuparidhāvati anuparivattati;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api nāma sā gaddula baddhaḥ daḷhe thambhe vā khile vā upanibaddhaḥ tam eva thambham vā khilam vā anuparidhāvati anuparivattati
translated: just as a dog tied by a leash to a strong post runs and circles around that same post.

original: evamevime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sakkāyabhayā sakkāyaparijegucchā sakkāyaññeva anuparidhāvanti anuparivattanti.
analyzed: evam eva ime bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā sakkāya bhayā sakkāya parijegucchā sakkāyaññā iva anuparidhāvanti anuparivattanti
translated: In the same way, these good recluses and brahmins, frightened and disgusted by the danger in the self, run and wander about within the self.

original: ‘Tayidaṁ saṅkhataṁ oḷārikaṁ atthi kho pana saṅkhārānaṁ nirodho atthetan’ti—
analyzed: tayā idam saṅkhatam oḷārikam atthi kho pana saṅkhārānam nirodhaḥ attha itanti
translated: ‘This is conditioned, gross, and a mere indication. But there is an unconditioned reality, a supreme security from bondage, where these things cease.’

original: iti viditvā tassa nissaraṇadassāvī tathāgato tadupātivatto.🔽Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṁ
analyzed: iti viditvā tassa nissaraṇa dassāvī tathāgato tad upātivatto  ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā aparanta kappikāḥ aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ aparanta
translated: Having known thus, the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the Accomplished in Knowledge and Conduct, the Well-Gone One, the Cogniser of the World, the Trainer of Men to be tamed, the Teacher of Gods and men, the Buddha, the Blessed One, has gone beyond that.

original: ārabbha anekavihitāni adhivuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imāneva pañcāyatanāni
analyzed: ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhivutti padāni abhivadanti sabbe te imān eva pañca āyatanāni
translated: “Whatever recluses and brahmins are speculators about the future, holding settled views about the future, and assert various doctrinal propositions about the future, all of them do so on the basis of these five aggregates or on the basis of one or another of them.

original: abhivadanti etesaṁ vā aññataraṁ.
analyzed: abhivadanti etesam vai aññatara
translated: They assert various doctrinal propositions about the future either on the basis of the material form aggregate subject to clinging, or on the basis of the feeling aggregate subject to clinging … the perception aggregate subject to clinging … the volitional formations aggregate subject to clinging … the consciousness aggregate subject to clinging.

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhivuttipadāni abhivadanti.
analyzed: santi bhikkhave eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbanta kappikā pubbanta anudiṭṭhino pubbantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhivutti padāni abhivadanti
translated: “There are, monks, some recluses and brahmins who are speculators about the past, holding settled views about the past, and they assert various doctrinal propositions concerning the past on the basis of the past.

original: ‘Sassato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: sassataḥ attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: They say: ‘The self and the world are eternal—this alone is the truth, (all) else is folly.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti, ‘asassato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—🔽ittheke abhivadanti, ‘sassato ca asassato ca attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti a sassataḥ attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti  itthā ike abhivadanti sassato ca a sassato ca attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: Some say: ‘The self and the world are not eternal. This alone is the truth, other ideas are foolish.’🔽Some say: ‘The self and the world are both eternal and not eternal.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti, ‘nevasassato nāsassato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti na iva sassataḥ na a sassataḥ attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: Some say: ‘The self and the world are neither eternal nor not eternal.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti, ‘antavā attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—🔽ittheke abhivadanti, ‘anantavā attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—🔽ittheke abhivadanti, ‘antavā ca anantavā ca attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti antavā attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti  itthā ike abhivadanti anantavā attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti  itthā ike abhivadanti antavā ca anantavā ca attā ca ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: Some say: ‘The self and the world are finite.’🔽Some say: ‘The self and the world are infinite.’🔽Some say: ‘The self and the world are both finite and infinite.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti, ‘nevantavā nānantavā attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti na ivantavā na anantavā attā ca ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: Some say: ‘The self and the world are neither finite nor infinite.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti, ‘ekattasaññī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti ekatta saññī attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: Some say: ‘The self and the world are one.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti, ‘nānattasaññī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—🔽ittheke abhivadanti, ‘parittasaññī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti nānatta saññī attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti  itthā ike abhivadanti paritta saññī attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: Some say, ‘The self and the world are percipient of variety. This alone is the truth, (all) else is foolish.’🔽Some say, ‘The self and the world are percipient of the limited. This alone is the truth, (all) else is foolish.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti, ‘appamāṇasaññī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—🔽ittheke abhivadanti, ‘ekantasukhī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti appamāṇa saññī attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti  itthā ike abhivadanti ekanta sukhī attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: Some say, ‘The self and the world are percipient of the infinite. This alone is the truth, (all) else is foolish.’🔽Some say, ‘The self and the world are entirely happy. This alone is the truth, (all) else is foolish.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti, ‘ekantadukkhī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—🔽ittheke abhivadanti, ‘sukhadukkhī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti ekanta dukkhī attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti  itthā ike abhivadanti sukha dukkhī attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: Some say, ‘The self and the world are entirely miserable. This alone is the truth, (all) else is foolish.’🔽Some say, ‘The self and the world are partly happy and partly miserable. This alone is the truth, (all) else is foolish.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti, ‘adukkhamasukhī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti adukkham asukhī attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: Some say, ‘The self and the world are neither happy nor miserable. This alone is the truth, (all) else is foolish.’

original: ittheke abhivadanti.
analyzed: itthā ike abhivadanti
translated: This is the third view.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ eva vādinaḥ eva diṭṭhinaḥ
translated: Here, monks, those ascetics and brahmins who are of this argument, this view,

analyzed: sassataḥ attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti tesam vata aññatra iva saddhāya
translated: ‘The self and the world are eternal—this alone is the truth, (all) else is foolish’:

analyzed: aññatra ruciyā aññatra anussavāḥ aññatra ākāra parivitakkāḥ aññatra diṭṭhi nijjhāna kkhantiyā  paccattayā iva ñāṇam bhavissati parisuddham pariyodātantinā itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: apart from faith, apart from approval, apart from oral tradition, apart from reasoned cogitation, apart from reflective acceptance of a view,🔽there is no ground for the view that there is a self.

translated: But, monks, when there is no ground for the view that there is a self, then, monks, for those good people🔽who are in the habit of relying on a ground for the view that there is a self, that is said to be clinging on their part.

analyzed: tayā idam saṅkhatam oḷārikam atthi kho pana saṅkhārānam nirodhaḥ attha itanti

analyzed: iti viditvā tassa nissaraṇa dassāvī tathāgato tad upātivatto
translated: Having known this, the Realised One, seeing the escape from it, has gone beyond it.

analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ eva vādinaḥ eva diṭṭhinaḥ
translated: Therein, monks, those ascetics and brahmins who are of this argument, this view,

analyzed: a sassataḥ attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññanti pe  sassato ca a sassato ca attā ca loko ca
